original: Bratt, Klas Gottfrid, fd. dövstum-präst, Räppe, f. 1/11/78 i Växjö av fabr. Alfred B. o. Hilda Andéhn. G. 10 m. Charlotta Maria Elisabeth Hagelberg. Barn: Anna-Lisa f. 12. ■— Mog:ex. i Växjö 97, teol. fil. ex. 98, teol. kand. 07, prakt. teol. prov samt prästv. f. Växjö stift 08. Kommin. i Gnosjö 10, präst i andra dövstumsk:-distr. 14, inom Lunds dövstumpräst-distr. 38. Und. samma tider förest, f. föreläsn rverksamh. i de båda distr., insp. f. föreläsn iverksamh. i Hovmantorp 17-25, ombud f. miss :styr. 29, sekr. i Växjö stifts miss :råd 30, led. av styr. f. dövstumhemm. Berghem i Hovmantorp 32, av stift. Växjö stifts prästänkehem 34, av styr. f. Vilhel-jninahemm. i Växjö 35, led. av diakonistyr. dövstumvårdsråd 39. Skr.: Jul-hälsn. t. dövstumma (14-38), Från de dövstummas värld (27), Siffror som tala (33), Oskar Tetzell (35), art. i Kyrka o. Hem m. fl. LVO.
translated: Bratt, Klas Gottfrid, former deaf and mute priest, Räppe, born on November 1, 1878 in Växjö to factory owner Alfred B. and Hilda Andéhn. Married to Charlotta Maria Elisabeth Hagelberg on October 10. Children: Anna-Lisa born on December 12. He completed his teacher's exam in Växjö in 1897, bachelor's degree in theology in 1898, candidate's degree in theology in 1907, practical theology exam and priest's ordination from Växjö Diocese in 1908. He served as a curate in Gnosjö in 1910, a priest in the second deaf and mute parish district in 1914, and within Lund's deaf and mute priest district in 1938. During the same period, he was an instructor and lecturer in both districts, an inspector for lecture activities in Hovmantorp from 1917-1925, a representative for the mission board in 1929, secretary in Växjö Diocese's mission council in 1930, a board member for the deaf and mute home Berghem in Hovmantorp in 1932, a member of the board for Växjö Diocese's widows' home in 1934, a board member for the Vilhelmina home in Växjö in 1935, and a member of the deaconess board for the deaf and mute care council in 1939. He wrote Christmas greetings to the deaf and mute (1914-1938), From the World of the Deaf and Mute (1927), Numbers that Speak (1933), Oskar Tetzell (1935), and articles in Church and Home among others. He was awarded the Litteris et Artibus medal.
